reviewText:
Deadwood is simply one of the best TV shows ever. Savage, bloody and profane-Deadwood also pulsates with a deeply moral core. This 3rd series has a few flat spots and superflous characters, but it's arguably the most tense and exciting of the three. And there's more of the wonderful black humour to go with typically jarring and brutal passages of violence. The acting, casting and production are magnificent-and of course there's the peerless dialogue that makes for transcedent televison.

Plot follows the tyrannical and murderous George Hurst's quest to own Mrs Ellsworth's rich gold claim. Anybody whose seen Series 2 will remember Hurst's creepily homicidal Lt. Mr Wolcott, well Hurst himself makes him look like a cream puff. Gerald McRaney essays Hurst with such a vicious amorality that we are in no doubt the entire town is in dire peril.

Leading the stand for Deadwood is, of course, Al Swearengen (Brilliantly played by Ian McShane as per usual) and the ever volatile Seth Bullock (Timothy Olyphant). It's these two and the rest of the exceptional cast  that make Deadwood must see viewing. It's a tribute to how good this is that most fans will gagging for the promised TV movies that will bring this superb series to a close.

The abrupt, ignominious, disasterously deflated ending of this scabrously funny, gut-clenchingly taut series was one of the greatest letdowns in TV history.  Other than those last two episodes and the facile resolution to the threat presented by Mr. Hearst, though, this was an awesome season of hard-hitting adult storytelling bliss.  Incredible acting, suspenseful stories, lots of creative language.

It's a pity that David Milch and HBO couldn't work their differences out -- the world is a much poorer place without Al Swearengen in it.

The third, and possibly final, season of HBO's critically acclaimed Deadwood had it's share of slow moving moments to be sure, but the series as a whole lived up to the excellent precedent set by the previous two seasons of the show.  As the third season opens, sheriff Seth Bullock (Timothy Olyphant) makes a run for re-election, which gets side tracked by forging an uneasy alliance with Al Swearengen (Ian McShane) against the vendictive George Hearst (Gerald McRaney) who comes to the camp with some deadly plans for everyone involved.  The lives of newly weds Alma Garret (Molly Parker) and Whitney Ellsworth (Jim Beaver), as well as Sol (John Hawkes) and Trixie (Paula Malcomson) are in jeopardy as Hearst prepares to wreak bloody havoc, which is mainly what this season of the series is focused on.  Also during this season, we witness the recovery of Cy (Powers Boothe), as well as bonding between Calamity Jane (Robin Weigert) and Joanie (Kim Dickens), and the debilitating health of Doc Cochran (Brad Dourif).  If you've been a fan of the show for some time, you know what to expect with Deadwood in terms of it's vulgarity and violence, so if you're new to the show, you won't really be won over by anything here.  That being said, the third season of Deadwood is some truly great TV regardless, and the ensemble cast as usual is superb; with Olyphant, McShane, and McRaney being the best of the bunch.  As the previous reviewer stated, if this is indeed the final season of the show with no other kind of resolution, there isn't any real cliffhanger that leaves the viewer cursing at the screen (a la Carnivale).  That being said, hopefully this isn't the last hurrah for Deadwood, and there will be another chapter before these characters ride off into the sunset.

"Deadwood" either is your cup of tea or isn't, and if it isn't, then you probably have no business even considering prchasing these DVDs; the third season in't gonna change your mind.  If it IS your cup of tea, and you're just wondering whether or not the third season meets the high marks set by the first two seasons, allow me to answer: it does.  In some cases, it even surpasses them.

The third season finds the camp in a general tizzy about the upcoming elections for mayor and sheriff, and Al Swearengen in a bit more specific tizzy about the impact the arrival of George Hearst has had on his life and livelihood.  In a sense, the entire season is about the power play between these two titans, with Cy Tolliver trying to edge himself into the mix somewhere and Seth Bullock trying to figure out what his place is in the whole mess.

Amongst the other plot threads explored in this season: Jane's growing friendship with the increasingly troubled Joanie Stubbs; Alma's opening a Deadwood bank; the feud between Steve and Hostetler; the oddly touching relationship between Trixie and Sol; Elsworth's marriage to Alma, which may not prove to be the bed of roses he had hoped for; the appearance in town of the Earp brothers, and of a troupe of actors; and, of course, Seth Bullock's ever-present willingness to be grumpy with the wrong person, Farnum's weasly nature, and Merrick's desire to write about it all.

The plots don't matter much, though.  The dialogue and the acting are what make this show great.  "Deadwood," in its three seasons, had so many iconic moments that it makes most other shows look like film-school projects in comparison.

In addition to the regular cast standouts -- Timothy Olyphant, Ian McShane, W. Earl Brown, William Sanderson, Brad Dourif, Molly Parker, Powers Boothe, Robin Weigert, and so on, ALL of whom do Emmy-caliber work -- I think special mention needs to go to Gerald McRaney, who turned up right at the end of season two but becomes an integral character in the third.  His portrayal of Hearst is just awesome.  Not that he's better than anyone else on the show; he just immediately fits in with the tone of the show, so much so that it really feels as if his character had been there all along, lurking in the shadows somewhere.

Much has been written about the fact that HBO decided to cancel the series, and pretty unexpectedly; but don't fret too much about the show ending on a cliffhanger.  Not all plot points are resolved, but there is at least a sort of closure; it's like the first two seasons, where it feels as if a chapter has ended, but the novel will continue.  Well, it looks like the novel WON'T be continuing -- HBO has claimed that there will be two two-hour movies to wrap things up, but no filming dates seem to have been set, and it's been months since anyone had anything to say about that project -- but if the series has to end with the close of the third season, I won't feel as if I was cheated too terribly badly.  I'd prefer it had run for ten or twelve years, but hey, we're lucky the doggone thing ever even got made.

As a history buff with a fascination for pioneer stories, this hits every mark with me.  I love being transformed into this (real) 1870s mining town, the characters are deep and likable.  From the down trodden prostitute Trixie who kills and then rises up,  to stubborn, righteous Bullock who tries not be himself but can't help it.  Swearengen is my all time favorite, as a cantankerous leader, and villainous thug, yet a visionary and willing savior.  They all have interesting flaws and aspects that are relate-able.  I enjoy the level of detail, the scenes, especially the background (sets) which really set the tone and bring you there.  Some plots follow actual events (Wild Bill Hickok's murder) and characters which make it that much more compelling.  Not to mention, the writing is hysterical (truly brilliant).  Yes lots of "f" this and "c" that - but I accepted that was the lingo.  This show is truly one of a kind, and I am bummed to only have 3 seasons.

No question, it is a gory, crude, brutal show representing the western frontier at its worst made to represent something that likely never was, but it was engaging in its raw brutality.  Sad thing is there is no waiting for Season 4, there is no measuring its overall quality because after building a compelling story with historical figures it just stops after season 3 leaving its viewers to be only disgusted and without any answers as to the outcome of any stories introduced.  Prime Video may be making some good productions of their own now, I wonder if they will stick it to us paying customers like they do in purchasing shows that were never completed?

It's about life, the violent life of humans, and not just the physical aspect of it, but also the psychological. For me, the ending was realistic, but sad and anticlimactic--just like most of our lives are. So in that sense, it was about as perfect an ending as you could expect--remembering that this is a tale of a real mining camp in  the USA's 1870s Western Front, so in some degree, they had to stay true to history.

A whole new vocabulary we found difficult to keep from sliding into our everyday!  Sexuality was still overt and overdone but was not as grotesquely overdone like other would be epic shows such as Game of Thrones (the sex on that show made me literally nauseous).  I was rating this show a spectacular 5 stars all the way until..... the last episode.  I mean, I saw that there weren't many episodes left until the season ended began to wonder how the show could possibly pull it together but... wow.  The last episode just.. just... well.  They just dropped the ball.  It's almost like they all showed up on set and decided to do .. nothing.  I have never seen the worst season ender in all my life.  I looked at my husband and looked at his face.  He'd never seen a worse season ender.  Seriously.  Why did they bother?  I want all my time back for this season.  That CAN'T be the ending.  It can't.  I don't want to give spoilers so I won't.  But believe me when I say... anyone could have dreamed up a better ending than that.  I gave it three stars for the fantastic acting, the great costumes, the great sets, the great photography, the great story lines & character development and for keeping my husband and I entertained for so long- but for that ONE horrific ending, you are lucky I only took two stars!  Shame on whomever did that to such a remarkable cast of people.

Al Swearingen!  the second-most-complicated character in TV history (besides Tatiana Maslany in "Orphan Black"...what?..at last count she plays...like...8 different continuing, nuanced, totally-different, true-to-life characters??!!!...NUTS!!)  I started watching Deadwood b/c I finished "Justified" and needed an Olyphant fix.  But as Timothy Olyphant has stated before, his Deadwood lead character Seth Bullock is way cool but doesn't have nearly the number of interesting sides that Raylan Givens has in Justified.  And they never let him do "funny" with Seth - crying shame!  What kept me riveted through Deadwood seasons 1, 2 and 3 was Al Swearingen, who just when you thought you had his character's contours mapped and compartmentalized, spreads his wings in just a little different - albeit very important and necessary for the plot development of the show - direction.  And normally with just the slightest facial movements.  You never know exactly what's going to happen properly with Al Swearingen in any given show, and whatever he finally does always makes sense.  When it occurs in the context of a riveting story with many other very good performances, THAT is great writing.  And Ian McShane's acting just nails it.
Then, of course, there are other reasons that set Deadwood apart from any other show in the history of TV:  1) it's the most swearing show ever - period.  And it all seems natural given the environment.  But just riding along while the writers plumb the depths of TV profanity is worth the ride.  But then there are lots of other things, like...what show has EVER had a severed head play a significant supporting role (the Indian chief's head that Swearingen claims his is about to send off but never does, keeping it instead for his adverse, self-mocking, consternation muse)?  Too fun!  And then the dialogue...amazing...Deadwood is the closest thing to an attainable Shakespearean western.

Throughout its run, Deadwood was a quirky series filled with eccentric characters. With dialog sourced in equal parts from Shakespeare and a football locker room, commercialized sex and nudity, graphic violence, and substance abuse in the extreme, it was like no other western on television, before or since. But in the third season, the denizens of Deadwood coalesced into an incredibly amoral, dysfunctional family in response to an invading battalion of armed thugs in the employ of the wealthy psychopath, George Hearst. Gerald McRaney played Hearst as a man so evil that he spits in the face of one of his employees (twice!) and tells him he'd better not see him later, having wiped it off. While no one would mistake Deadwood for a comedy, the dialog was often hysterically funny, if you could only follow what they were saying. I have no idea why HBO decided to overplay it's hand with the actors, but the result was an unexpected termination after three spectacular seasons. Sorely missed, and highly recommended.

Deadwood is awesome and surprisingly relevant. I'm drawn to gritty period pieces, and this is arguably the grittiest, sweatiest, dirtiest period piece ever filmed. But the dramatic tension is intense, the characters riveting and loveable, even the grotesque monsters.

A quasi-historical series  that displays a depiction of the old west with all of its warts. I found the "bad-ass pimp" guy to be more of a "hero" than the figure of George Hearst. George Hearst was the father of William Hearst, a successful miner and businessman who went on to become a U.S. Senator ... even in those days "polite circles" welcomed the wealthy scoundrels. Nothing like a little union busting to gladden the heart.

Many of the characters in the series have historical basis, Al Swearengen (real life pimp), Wild Bill Hickock, Wyatt Earp, Seth Bullock, George Hearst, Sol Star, Charlie Utter, E.B. Farnum, and Calamity Jane to name a few.

Recommended for your pleasure, but with the awareness that there is excessive violence and foul language.

All three seasons of this series were excellent in every way. Unlike many westerns, Deadwood required careful listening and needed to be watched a number of times to really comprehend what was going on and what was being said. The language used was complicated and almost Shakespearean in its rhythms, the character development was complex (as humans are). No one was completely good or bad, with the possible exception of children. As the series progressed, all the characters showed courage, cowardice, nobility and baseness. There were frequently disasters that resulted from the best possible motives. There was deterioration and elevation of all the characters. All three seasons make this one of the several best series ever on television, in all facets (writing, acting, casting- even multiple casting, casting against type, plotting, historical accuracy, sets, costumes). I put it right up there at the top along with Breaking Bad, Mad Men, the Wire. Rome, Game of Thrones. My only reservations are that it didn't run for more than three seasons
